I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course focuses mainly on translation of the Aeneid, with meter, grammar, poetic devises, and some secondary literature on the meaning, historical context and social implications of the work.

In this course we read Virgil's Aeneid book 3 in Latin, discussing both the grammar and vocabulary in Latin as well as the themes of the poem and the reception through the ages. We worked on the latin by going over the translation in class together and we developed the critical thinking aspect through secondary literature, short essays and discussions in class.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was truly an all-encompassing approach to the text, and this meant a high degree of engagement from each student, but also a very high reward of learning and understanding. Professor Kraus is rigorous and thoughtful, and certainly sets a high standard for the classroom every day.

Compared to the introductory level Latin class, I enjoyed the incorporation of the poetic interpretation aspect of the class. The secondary literature helped me think about the big themes and the study of the poem's reception brought on interesting discussions of the different repurposing of the material. Professor Kraus also showed us related artworks, artifacts and manuscripts and the visual aspect helped ground the discussion about some topics that are ancient and/or foreign.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The different forms of assessment were a great way of adjusting to the virtual format so that grading did not rest on merely online exams. The written assignments and discussions were a great way of combining skills in a remote format.
I think Professor Kraus was very flexible and accommodating towards the difficulties that arose because of remote learning and the pandemic.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would highly recommend this course to anyone looking to improve their Latin reading/grammar skills. I learned so much vocabulary and am now much better at translating Latin poetry. Professor Kraus is wonderful and Im so happy I took this course.

I would recommend this course to a student who is willing to prioritize the class and the workload, because the payoff of improving in reading Latin and uncovering so many layers of Roman history in reading the text is immense.

I would strongly recommend this class to another student. Compared to the introductory level Latin class, I enjoyed the incorporation of the poetic interpretation aspect of the class. The secondary literature helped me think about the big themes and the study of the poem's reception brought on interesting discussions of the different repurposing of the material. Professor Kraus also showed us related artworks, artifacts and manuscripts and the visual aspect helped ground the discussion about some topics that are ancient and/or foreign. The relative small size of the class helps one get to know the other students and creates a familiar, relaxed atmosphere. Overall it has been a good time!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
